How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Henry Glick  Very helpful.
Instructor: Henry Glick  He was very knowledgeable although I didn't need him much.

Instructor: Henry Glick  Strengths: 1) Same schedule for review sessions every week allowed students to plan ahead of time. 2) Instead of solving the problems and the questions, he encouraged people to think. 3) Very helpful and dedicated.

Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry clearly had a good grasp of the material, especially the mathematical aspects of it. However, I think he sometimes had a hard time answering simple questions in a simple, non-mathematical way for those of us who don't think in the same way.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Too many people to help in small window of time. Was very rhetorical at times, which was frustrating.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was always very available and encouraging. He was more than willing to help students brainstorm on difficult assignments.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry is great as he is now.

Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was a terrific TA for this course. He was consistently helpful and available. He provided many useful insights both for GIS skills and the larger scope of the class. I really appreciate his availability and hard work.
Instructor: Henry Glick  He was good.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was very prompt in responding to questions via Piazza, and gave clear explanations to help solve problems.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Very prompt response to our queries

Instructor: Henry Glick  Strengths: approachable, good at explaining material, very knowledgeable. Weaknesses: as best I could tell, preferred working with the stronger students, the students who started working with him earlier in the semester and worked with him weekly, and the students who clamored more loudly for assistance. To improve, even out the attention among students, and spend a bit more time with those who are struggling, even if they ask quietly. And, in all fairness, this course probably should have had two teaching fellows.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry's explanations were complex at time but he allocated enough time to support students
Instructor: Henry Glick  Strengths: patience, organized, knows the software, very available and always willing to support us in learning.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I wish that the assignments actually pertained to environmental issues. I dont understand why he gave us such random and abstract assignments when he knows that almost all the students of the class are FES students. I did not feel engaged at all in the assignments because very few of them had much to do with environmental problems. I want to use GIS to solve environmental problems, and so it would have been good to get practical experience in this during the class.
This is a valuable course, and I would like to see it taught in a computer lab.

Course instruction was often convoluted and unclear. Serious consideration should be placed on course structure for next year's class. The class would be well-served with a lab component, as it would more effectively engage students in course material during lectures.
Q13 On the instructor. I have never taken a class where the professor was as organized and responsive as Dana. He is the best.
Dana could be clearer with his expectations. He seems to set specific metrics for how the course material will be evaluated but then change these as he grades.

This was by far one of the most useful classes I've taken so far at FES, and also one of the most challenging. It requires a substantial commitment, but I highly recommend it to anyone who might encounter GIS in their careers.

If you did not performed well on the assignments, you did not learned the material because the professor did not explain the right approach on the following classes. Hit or miss type of class without the need of being that way.

Should be a flipped course or devote more time to doing homework in class with the guidance of TF and instructor. HW assignments take close to 12 hours each week and we could work more efficiently if given time to do something similar to the homework in class.
all questions

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: How much I learned. Boatloads. The handouts were very thorough and very helpful. The professor was also extremely responsive and clearly knows a ton about the program. I can't think of a time he didn't respond within 12 hours to a question, and his responses were almost always extremely helpful.
Became familiar with many of the analytical tools associated with raster GIS, which have a wide range of uses
The learning curve! I felt myself growing week by week, which is really the goal of any course.
Solid knowledge on ArcGIS through HW assignments.
I feel like I have a good handle on basic raster GIS and am excited to have this skill.
Learning to use GIS.
The homework assignments are well designed to exercise new concepts and build upon previous work. The instructor was also open to students using the course to work through their own projects.

Dana allowed us to pursue a project of our own interest, which motivated me to do better work and to explore the software more. Dana is a great instructor and clearly has a specific pedagogy, which I don't think is the case for all professors at FES.
Dr. Tomlin takes a very thoughtful approach in how he presents the material, and in how he responds to student questions, and is extremely responsive to student questions and input.
Great material, fun puzzley assignments

GIS is essential to so much work in the environment. The ESRI product, taught in this course, and such as it is, is the state of the art. All in all, the projects have value in teaching many of the technicalities of the software instrument.

The course was very well organized and structured. It was very easy to see how the lecture connected to the homework assignments, which reinforced what we learned in class by giving us a chance to actually use the tools we were introduced to. The instructor obviously has a very strong expertise of ArcGIS and was very good at explaining it and answering questions.
The different tools learnt and technical skills gained each week
Clear instruction and demostration
The assignments were challenging and forced us to put in practice the tools we learned in class.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: structure and content of assignments

The grading. Professor Tomlin would make up criteria after the fact, and how folks did from week to week, and even what assignments would end up counted in grades, seemed quite random. For example, Professor Tomlin decided toward the end to grade in three segments: the first half of the course, the second half of the course, and the final project, and then drop one of the three. Students who maybe averaged HP within both halves and then got an H on the final project then did worse than students who maybe had a P in the first half, an H in the second half, and an H on the final, even though those two performance records would otherwise be about equal. I also found the curve really discouraging. For example, the brainteasers, which were supposedly extra credit, really became required for folks who wanted high grades because of the eventual allocation of semester grades according to a predetermined distribution, further expanding the already large course workload. The inherent competition in curves, too, just seems very against FES culture. One of my favorite aspects of FES is how non-competitive it is. I'd rather there be objective standards for what constitutes an H, HP, etc., even strict and hard-to-reach standards, than a curve.
Grading rules and parameters should be established before each homework is assigned. In that sense people would have a clear knowledge on how they are going to be graduated.

Professor Tomlin's grading system is opaque, and it is difficult to know what criteria he will use to assess students work until after the work is finished. Also, we received very little instruction on creating dynamic models, which we needed to know in order to complete the final assignment. While being able to use model builder is helpful, it is my impression that it is rarely used by professionals because model builder is clunky and similar functions can be preformed more easily using Python programming language.
I would like to see this course taught in a computer lab.

The expectations and workload for the class should be re-evaluated. Students were often not taught the skills and concepts necessary to perform well on homework assignments. Homework grading seemed entirely arbitrary, and students were not made aware of the grading structure prior to submitting assignments.
None. Workload is too heavy?
Towards the end of the course the lectures on modeling did not seem to be particularly well related to the homework, which led to lots of frustration in completing the project.

A lot of the time I did not understand what the instructor was talking about. It might be helpful to use slides with the examples drawn out. Also, it would be nice to tell students early in the course how heavy the course load is.

More transparency regarding grading rubric for weekly hw assignments - the grading rubric was sent AFTER assignments were due to explain grades, but this doesn't help students who would like more guidance on what is being asked of them for each assignment.
Sometimes the homework assignments were frustrating in that the instructions were vague.
Too much psychological messing with.

Clarity at the beginning of the semester concerning how the course will be graded - and then proper follow-through. More tool-use practice time during class. Staying with what we are told will be done, or giving us some choice in the switches. Not dropping assigned group projects from the grading. Not dropping some of the most challenging weeks from the grading without some input from the class. What a painful waste of time and effort. Not wasting significant portions of two classes outlining how grading will be done -- then failing to follow through on the outline. The software itself is clunky, slightly buggy, non-intuitive. It is state-of-the art, but it should be better.

The assignments need to be related to the environment. Dana tries to make everything ridiculously hard- like a puzzle that must be solved. In that attempt, he misses the fact that these assignments need to be based on real issues within the environmental field.
there need to be incorporation of group work from start to end of the course If Dana could record his lecturer they would be helpful for review

Having more tutorials as we did for the vector course would have been great. I found those very helpful for reinforcing what we were taught in class last semester but sadly this semester it was not the case.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I really appreciate Henry's availability and expertise in office hour sessions.
Course lectures were specifically designed to present us with the tools we needed to complete the assignments.
It was effective and well coordinated
It was.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I need ArcGIS skills for my research and for future jobs.
I believe this GIS is a very good skill to analyze and tackle problems from another perspective. Additionally, I believe visual representation of analysis is far more powerful than just figures.
I was happy to have a class that directed me through the use of a number of analytical GIS skills that I am likely to use in my professional life after school.
This course offers tangible skills that are applicable across a wide range of science fields.
I intend to work in land conservation, so an understanding of spatial analysis is critical, whether I'm working with GIS myself, or communicating with users of the software.
I will learn ArcGIS (raster) for my thesis.
GIS systems will be crucial to many of us for our future careers. I gained a lot form taking the course.
As a social scientists, GIS has helped me explore questions about the spatial components of demographic and political trends, which I am excited to continue working on.

I had very little GIS experience coming into this course, and feel that I've gained a much greater understanding of the concepts of GIS and spatial analysis and now would feel confident applying GIS in a professional setting. I also plan to incorporate elements of GIS, and specifically concepts learned in this course, to my research.
GIS is a fantastic skill to have in environmental work and is essential to some environmental work.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I want to use GIS during my professional career to solve environmental and social problems
I need ArcGIS skills for my research and for future jobs.
I was interested in getting concrete, transferable skills for geospatial analysis.
I took vector in the fall and wanted to continue learning how to use the software.
To learn the fundamentals of raster GIS
To be exposed to a new set of skills.
I took the vector course and enjoyed it, and decided that this would be a valuable skillset to build out more.

I was sort of interested in GIS based on previous work experience, but initially did not plan on taking this class. However, after attending classes during shopping period I was convinced that this would be a highly useful course, and that learning this skill from Dr. Tomlin would be a great advantage to me in my career.
I plan to use GIS in my career in managing natural resources.
I wanted to get some mapping experience for my MF degree.
it fits well with my water resource management specialization

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I did gain valuable knowledge and skills but it would have been much better if the assignments were more applicable and not so abstract.
Yes. Definitely.
YES
Yes
Yes! I am pleased with the tangible skills I gained this semester.
I felt like the material was much more conceptual and less practical than that covered in the vector class, which is only useful to a certain extent.
Absolutely. Exceeded.
yes
Yes.
Yes
Yes
Yes.
Yes, very much
yes
yes

Yes, and no. I know significantly more GIS than I did in August. Practice exercises, in class trial of tools, some follow-through, more re-use of previously taught tools... all of these would improve one's ability to build up mastery. The ESRI product is enormous. Even as intense as the GIS courses are, there is no way to completely cover what the program can do. Whether I have met a minimum needed to work in the field remains to be seen!
Yes.
Yes, the skills did
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Working in groups is absolutely essential to GIS - especially in Dana's classes which are extremely difficult. Without group work I would never have made it through this class. We all work together to help each other through assignments and to give each other suggestions. We still usually do independent work but being able to talk with others about your ideas and questions is very important in this class.
Helped me learn. I liked that the groups were optional, though, since sometimes they're hard to coordinate and it's easier to work alone.
I highly recommend working in group. Assignments are more difficult than the vector course and having someone to interact and discuss your problems in real time is a great way to solve problems.
It was hard to coordinate with group members, and didn't add to my learning. Working informally with other students was very helpful, though.
It was a pain as group projects usually are.
Work done faster
We used our strengths and finished an assignment in a shorter amount of time.

Since the work that was assigned as group work was not counted in the final grade, this work, a significant amount of time, proved to be a colossal waste of time. Such time is not recoverable and has an adverse effect on many aspect of one's studies.
It was very helpful to do the homework assignments in groups, or at least work on the assignments with other people, because we would help each other through difficulties.
Work completion is slower but students understand the course concepts better
I usually work individually, but once worked with a friend in the team project. Although team working did not make faster progress but it does help mitigating the frustration during problem solving.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Read Dana's handouts

If you want an H, this course will take over your entire life. Tons of work. Or, if you're fine with an HP and reasonably good at computer-based/analytical work, you can do six hours a week and do just fine.
Take it. However, be prepared to spend a lot of time on this.

Don't invest Dana's grading system with too much importance. You'll learn a lot from doing the assignments, but at a certain point you can spend hours making it look nice for a better grade, but will learn very little from doing so.
Be prepared to spend a significant chunk of time each week working on your weekly assignment. Also, complete Dana's handout readings!
This course is very challenging and extremely time consuming. Consider whether it essential for you future work. I would also suggest taking the fall vector class prior to taking this spring course.
This course takes up so much of your time, but if you commit to it, it will be the best class you will ever take!
Take advantage of Henry's office hours and try to do most of the work then.
I would advise them to take it. But I would caution them that it is an incredible amount of work.
Prepare to commit a lot of time and hours of muddling through, but you will become highly proficient with this software.
It is a great course, and Dr. Tomlin is a terrific teacher. I highly recommend the class, however you should expect to need to commit a substantial amount of time to the class.
Hard course but fun brain stretch and worthwhile skills; Dana is an uncommonly good explainer of complex ideas.
Take it!
It is an excellent class. If you are ready to invest enough time to learn the course, it will be worth the time. There are no shortcuts to learning it. You either commit fully or you don't.

To learn GIS, these courses are the only game in town. Take the course(s) -- vector GIS, raster GIS (this course) and maybe the Python course. Professor Tomlin is certainly expert in his knowledge of all thing GIS, an he is responsive to the voiced needs of individual students, so voice your needs. Ask for clarity on grading early in the course. Ask for more class time using the program. Know that the weekly projects are very challenging and require a steady commitment to complete.
I would suggest spending time reviewing the handouts to read about the tools we were introduced to in class before trying to dive into the homework assignments.
The course provides good technical skills in raster GIS but is time demanding. At least 8-10 hours are required per week besides the class
Take it if you're interested in learning the subject but be ready to put a lot of hours to complete the assignments.
